caption: There is something so beautiful about the immense size of the statues and the roundabout on nation’s square.

Beautiful space and lots to see. There's so much history here. Watch out for scammers and pickpockets here too, but take the time to take in the space. This is also an area often shown on TV with the kids and fountains and boats. Very pretty.

The park features a beautiful landscape, characterized by impressive architecture and the distinctive aesthetic of French art. It offers a delightful setting to indulge in an ice cream and savor the vibrant atmosphere of a bustling metropolis.
Walking around here is so nice you can sitting down on the bench of the park reading books, or you can enjoy the coffee at the coffeeshop nearby and shopping as well.

Very pretty square with an imposing sculpture in the middle. A lot of people go there to walk their dogs, and as a middle point for many main avenues in this part of the town. There's also a metro station, with connections to the major parts of the city. Close to the Place are tobacco stores and some cozy some bars. It's even, perhaps, a good place to sit down and relax to read or drink something with friends.
So romantic places
Nice spot to chill. There's are some trees so you have easily shade and also sun. The grass is proper and generally is not so crowded.

This historical square was originally known as the Place du Trone as it had a throne in it, then a guillotine during the French Revolution, and lastly an impressive statue you can still admire today. When you look back at the history of the Place de la Nation, the square was originally named the Place du Trone, which generally translates to Place of the Throne in English, and this was due to the fact that a throne was actually put in place in 1660.  And this was erected in the square in the July of that year ready for the arrival of Louis XIV and Maria Theresa of Spain after their marriage. At the time, this square in Paris was actually located in countryside outside of the city limits, yet in the 1780s the very unpopular Wall of the Farmers General, or Mur des Germiers Generaux in French, was being constructed from the designs of the architect in charge, Claude Nicolas Ledoux.  Now this wall was designed to have gates in order to obtain taxes on goods entering the city, and the one located here was called the throne gate with its impressive columns, or Colonnes de la Barriere du Trone, as they are called.  And these can still be seen today close to the Place de la Nation along with the two pavilions that were erected called the Barrier du Trone or Pavillons du Trone.

Beautiful place, easily acessed and with great options of bars, restaurants, bistrots, supermarkets and a beautiful church nearby. We visited during the final of Champions League and it was packed, but great nonetheless.

Place de la Nation, formerly known as "Place du Trone" and then "Place de Trone-Renversie", is a square in Paris located on the border of the 11th and 12th arrondissements of the city. This square was historically the scene of the largest number of executions by guillotine during the French Revolution of 1789
Stayed 1 Bis Cite Voltaire during 1990's. Wonderful park and area with buz - central to public transport

Place de la Nation is a large square located in the 11th and 12th arrondissements of Paris, France. It is one of the largest and most important traffic junctions in the city. The square was originally called Place du Trône ("Throne Square") and was renamed Place de la Nation in 1880, on the occasion of the national holiday celebrating the storming of the Bastille. The Place de la Nation is a popular spot for tourists and locals alike. The Colonne du Trône, a 52-meter-tall column that was built in 1810 to commemorate the victories of the French army.
Beautiful park,sculpture
Very nice and quiet.. great for reading or contemplating..

Nice statue. Just another place out of many to wind down and chill. There's a metro nearby and electric scooter/bicycle parking spot just across the road if you travel by Lime. There are a few benches provided too.

A huge roundabout decorated by a sculpture called “the Triumph of the republic. Located in the eastern part of Paris, it’s on the verge of the 11th & 12th arrondissements. Historically, this plaza witnessed the most guillotine death sentences during the 1789 French Revolution.
Great experience and lots of bars

Stayed in this neighborhood for a weekend in September 2019. Very convenient to all underground lines, 20 minutes to Eiffel tower. Located on the border of the 11th and 12th arrondissements. Non-tourist area so they expect you to know a little conversational French.
The statue is amazing but looks a little unloved with graffiti all over it, and the area around looks a bit shabby.
Nice place, close to the metro, bus station, grocery stores, calm area
My first stay at paris is a wonderful view.i love it
Stayed in this district, loads of eateries, easy access to metro, buses, taxi. Lovely bakeries and monuments were nice to look at, atmosphere lovely.
Nice community meeting place, full of history just like anywhere in Paris.
Amazing statue, a place that must be seeing at Paris. Paco on with he's new photos!!
Great graffiti on the statue. Complete with weed smoking teenagers. Excellent. Très bon. I highly recommend.
It has delicious boulangeries
Quiet and peaceful neighborhood with a variety of transportation

It has definitely changed a lot since i last came here. There are seats along the sides for people to rest. Its pleasant to look at and to just sit for awhile before taking the metro to where you want to go next.
Lovely park in a nice part of Paris
Lovely place with greenery and à magnificant Statue de Marianne!

This should be a good case study for people who are looking to change a car dominant space into something more mixed where cars, bikes and pedestrians can live together. The new Place de la Nation is a clear urban planning success, Congrats!

Roundabout traffic can be a bit annoying. Was much better in ‘94 during the height of the Revolution, when the Place was filled with the guillotined heads of traitors of the republic. Great burgers at Chez Prosper. Scantily dressed sculpture of a woman in the middle might be inappropriate for families with children. Nice tiger, however.

Beautiful, elegant and historical, a good place to visit. Well connected to RER A and several bus lines, excellent cycling paths and great for a walk in those elegant boulevards. There are many options for eat and drink.
It is a quiet place, safe, with lots of restaurants and shops with a variety of prices. Metro, bus and Rer are all available. 30 minutes metro ride from centre.
Place of nation had been very clumsy for traffic.  Now it is much better after renovation some years ago, just before Covid-19.  With traffic lights installed, the square is much more reasonable.

Great hub trains get you everywhere in Paris with ease. Some major lines end at this point. Close to some beautiful parks and cemeteries. And it hosts an awesome market with produce, clothes, honey, butcher and cheese vendors

The 2 columns of Nation Place in France like those on place de  l’étoile have been built to counter tax fraud on incoming commodities affecting the income of French Kingdom of the late 18th century just before the French Revolution. Now these are part of Paris historical monuments.
If it wasnt in Paris it would be amazing
